item.title: Small Business Idea: EcoCompute AI: Pinpoint & Prune Idle AI Cloud Costs
item.content:encoded:
The era of AI is upon us, but it comes with a silent, significant cost: ever-ballooning cloud bills and a growing carbon footprint from inefficient compute. Training and inference for AI models devour resources, often leaving behind forgotten, idle, yet still-billing instances. This is where you, the agile indie developer, come in.

Brief Description of the Idea: Create 'EcoCompute AI,' a minimalist tool that helps developers and small teams identify and eliminate wasted cloud spend associated with idle or underutilized AI/ML compute resources. It translates complex cloud metrics into clear, actionable insights for both cost savings and environmental impact reduction.

Core Value Proposition: 'Save substantial money and reduce your carbon footprint by intelligently identifying and acting on underutilized AI/ML cloud infrastructure.'

Target Customers: Individual data scientists, ML engineers, small AI/ML focused startups, and development teams within larger organizations that manage their own cloud infrastructure on AWS, GCP, or Azure and are acutely aware of their monthly cloud spend.

Minimum Viable Product (MVP) Scope for Day One: You have exactly one day. Focus ruthlessly. Your Day One MVP is an 'Idle AWS GPU Instance Detector.'

  1. CLI Tool: Build a simple Python (or Node.js) command-line interface.
  2. AWS Authentication: Require AWS credentials (e.g., AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY in environment variables) and a region.
  3. Instance Listing: Use boto3 (or AWS SDK equivalent) to list all running EC2 instances in the specified region.
  4. GPU Instance Filtering: Filter this list to specifically identify instances known for AI/ML workloads, particularly those with GPUs (e.g., p2, p3, g4dn series instances).
  5. GPU Utilization Check: For each identified GPU instance, query AWS CloudWatch for the GPUUtilization metric over the last 24 hours.
  6. Idle Detection Logic: If the maximum GPUUtilization reported for a given instance over that 24-hour period is less than 5% (indicating near-idle status), flag it.
  7. Output: Print a clean, formatted list to the console showing: Instance ID, Instance Type, and a clear message: 'Potentially idle GPU instance â€“ investigate for cost savings.' (Optional: an estimated hourly cost if you can hardcode common types or quickly fetch pricing).

This MVP provides immediate, tangible value: identifying forgotten, expensive resources. It proves the core concept with minimal dependencies and no complex UI. The value is obvious: find idle GPU machines that are costing hundreds, if not thousands, of dollars per month. From here, you build out integrations, more complex detection, and beautiful dashboards.
